repnme.cdata!: India - Second National Leprosy Elimination Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is highly likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial; Bank
            performance is satisfactory; Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. Overall, the project provided the Bank with an
            opportunity to gain valuable experience in shifting
            ownership and responsibility for vertical disease control
            programs to the states, increasing state-level capacity to
            take on the new role, and strengthening central capacity for
            policy guidance, technical support, surveillance and
            advocacy. Specific lessons include: 1) Decentralization can
            transform the program by shifting ownership and
            responsibility to the states. However, this needs to be
            backed up with a strong capacity building component.
            Establishing sustainable systems and maintaining quality at
            the state level require a strong central hub, providing
            overall support on several fronts: (a) accessing and
            disseminating best practices; (b) setting standards and
            developing appropriate guidelines; (c) mustering a group of
            advocates; (d) monitoring the disease at the national level;
            and (e) brainstorming about future strategies and
            sustainability. 2) An internationally established end-point
            serves as a rallying point. The project had the advantage of
            a well-recognized, internationally accepted outcome:
            'elimination of leprosy' 3) Involving all
            stakeholders from early on is essential; some of the cadre
            problems encountered in pockets across the country could
            have been avoided by adopting a more participatory approach.
            4) Stringent monitoring is a must. Tracking and analyzing
            data by gender and castes/tribal categories has been a very
            useful tool in particular for targeting inputs. 5) An
            effective education program, coupled with enhanced quality
            of services, has boosted voluntary reporting and early
            diagnosis of cases by reducing fear and stigma, and provided
            clear information regarding the availability of services. 6)
            Public-Private Partnerships need to be well defined, and
            expanded and sustained. 7) Having one umbrella organization
            as the intermediary - the International Federation of
            Anti-Leprosy Associations - has made managing and monitoring
            the partnership with NGOs simpler.

repnme.cdata!: India - Second National Leprosy Elimination Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second National Leprosy Elimination
            Project for India transforms the national leprosy control
            program into an effective and sustainable program through a
            decentralized and integrated approach which increases
            community access to multi-drug therapy. There are five
            project components. The first component focuses on
            decentralization and institutional development. The second
            component strengthens and integrates service delivery,
            namely financing incremental operating costs, drug delivery,
            campaigns, and training, activities to target special
            groups, and service delivery by non-governmental
            organizations. The third component focuses on disability
            prevention and finances purchase of services from
            nongovernmental organizations, consultant services,
            training, purchase of equipment, and operating expenses. The
            fourth component is an information, education, and
            communication component, carrying out political advocacy,
            and changing society's attitude to leprosy and
            increasing demand by affected individuals for leprosy
            control services. It finances consultant services,
            workshops, training, technical assistance, IEC materials,
            and media space and operational expenses. Finally, the fifth
            component reorients staff to an integrated approach and
            provides them new skills in the general health services,
            management skills, and technical skills.
